title: How to Make Cookies Without Flour

steps.headline: Use nuts or oats instead of flour.
steps.description: Flour acts as a binder to keep your cookies together. To replace flour as a binding agent, replace flour in your recipe with chopped nuts (like pecans, macadamia nuts, or walnuts) or rolled oats. These will bind your other ingredients together and help the cookies hold their shape as they bake. Try a no-bake chocolate oatmeal cookie or traditional flourless almond cookies. You could also try baking cookies using a ground nut flour or wheat germ.

steps.headline: Make an egg white-based cookie.
steps.description: Whip egg whites and use them as a binder for your cookies. Egg whites give texture to cookies and can make them chewy and crackly on the outside. Meringues and macarons are good examples of flourless cookies that rely on egg whites for body. You could also make mini-Pavlova cookies that are like little meringues. Fill these with fruit, nuts, or chocolate for a simple flourless dessert.

steps.headline: Try an alternative flour.
steps.description:
There are a lot of alternative flours available if you'd like to swap out traditional all-purpose flour for something that's less processed. To replace 1 cup of all-purpose flour in your cookie recipe, use one of the following:
3/4 cup of coarse cornmeal
3/4 cup of rice flour
1.5 cups of oat flour

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: Turn on the oven to 325 degrees F (162 degrees C). Lay a sheet of parchment paper onto your baking sheet. This will prevent the cookies from sticking to your baking sheet, making them easier to remove. If you're having trouble getting the parchment to lay flat on the baking sheet, spray the bottom of the baking sheet with cooking spray before you lay the parchment on it.

steps.headline: Chop the chocolate and pecans.
steps.description: Place 5 ounces (150 g) of bittersweet chocolate and 1 1/2 cups of pecans (or other nuts) on a large cutting board. Carefully chop the chocolate and nuts until they're the size of chocolate chips. Set these ingredients aside. You could use a food processor to chop the nuts and chocolate, if you don't want to chop them by hand. Just ensure not to chop the nuts and chocolate into a fine powder.

steps.headline: Combine your dry ingredients.
steps.description: In a large bowl, place 3 cups (330 g) of confectioners' sugar, 3/4 cup (88.5 g) of Dutch-process cocoa powder (spooned and leveled) and 1/2 teaspoon of coarse salt. Whisk the dry ingredients until the lumps are broken up and the cocoa is evenly distributed. The dry ingredients will be a uniform pale brown color once they're completely combined.

steps.headline: Separate the eggs.
steps.description: Have two small bowls on your work space next to the eggs. Your eggs should be at room temperature. Crack each egg and separate the yolk from the egg white. It's helpful to let the egg white fall into one bowl so you can place the egg yolk in the other bowl. Do this for every egg. Since you'll only need the egg whites, you can cover and refrigerate the egg yolks for another recipe (like lemon curd, creme brulee or a custard).

steps.headline: Combine the ingredients.
steps.description: Add the egg whites to your bowl of dry ingredients. Use a firm whisk to stir them completely. The dry ingredients will dissolve in the egg whites to create a dark thick cookie dough. Stir in the chopped nuts and chocolate. You can use a rubber spatula to stir in the chopped nuts and chocolate if the dough gets too thick. Check the bottom of the mixing bowl to ensure there isn't any flour or cocoa that hasn't been stirred in.

steps.headline: Scoop and bake the cookies.
steps.description: Use 1/4 cup measuring scoop or 1/4 cup ice cream scoop to scoop out your cookie dough onto the prepared sheets. Leave 3 inches of space between each cookie since they'll spread as they cook. Bake the cookies for 25 minutes. They'll become crisp and crackly on the outside when they're done. This recipe will make 12 flourless double-chocolate pecan cookies. You can store them in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven.
steps.description: Turn on your oven to 200 degrees F (95 degrees C). Put an oven rack in the center of your oven. Place a piece of parchment paper on each of your baking sheets. This will help the cookies release once they're baked. The oven temperature may seem low, but that's because these cookies bake for a very long time.

steps.headline: Beat the egg whites.
steps.description: Place 3 large egg whites into the bowl of a stand mixer or in a large mixing bowl. Beat the egg whites on medium speed for 1 minute, until it starts to foam and then softly peak. If you want, you can add 1/4 teaspoon of cream of tartar to help stabilize or firm up the egg whites (but this is optional if you don't have cream of tartar). The bowl and beaters need to be completely clean and free of grease. Check the egg whites to ensure that no yolk is in the bowl. These can prevent the egg whites from beating to full volume. Test for soft peaks by lifting your beater out of the bowl. The egg whites will lift up and droop down if they're at soft peak stage.

steps.headline: Add superfine sugar.
steps.description: Turn the mixer back on to medium speed and add 3/4 cup (150 grams) of superfine or caster sugar one tablespoon at a time. Beating the egg whites while slowly adding the sugar will allow it to dissolve into the egg whites. Gradually beating in the sugar will prevent the cookies from being gritty.

steps.headline: Beat the mixture until you get stiff shiny peaks.
steps.description: Turn the mixer up to medium-high speed and continue to beat the sugar and egg white mixture. Stop the mixture once or twice and scrape down the sides with a clean rubber spatula. Test for stiff peaks by lifting up the beater. The mixture should hold firm shiny peaks. Touch the mixture and rub it between your fingers. If it feels gritty, continue to beat it. When you no longer feel the sugar between your fingers, the meringue batter is ready to use.

steps.headline: Beat in any flavorings.
steps.description:
If you want to add a subtle flavor to the meringue cookies, beat in 1/4 teaspoon of extract. Consider what you'll be using the meringues for and what flavors you'll be serving them with. Popular extracts to use in meringues include:
Vanilla
Peppermint
Almond
Lemon

steps.headline: Form the meringue cookies.
steps.description: Take two large spoons and scoop up large dollops of meringue onto your parchment-lined baking sheets. You can scoop them close to each other because they won't spread much during baking. Make the meringue cookies as large or as small as you like, just be aware that larger cookies will take longer to bake. If you want more decorative meringues, pipe the meringues using a pastry bag and 1/2" tip.

steps.headline: Bake the meringue cookies.
steps.description: Place the baking sheets in the oven for 1 hour and 30 minutes to 1 hour and 45 minutes. The meringues will turn a light pale color and will crisp up as they bake and dry. Turn off the oven and return the meringues to the oven. Leave the door open and let them cool for several hours or overnight. This recipe will make about 9 medium to large size meringues. You can store the meringues in an airtight container for a few days.
